skill.name: tsdown
skill.description: Bundle TypeScript and JavaScript libraries with blazing-fast speed powered by Rolldown. Use when building libraries, generating type declarations, bundling for multiple formats, or migrating from tsup.
skill.summary: Bundle TypeScript and JavaScript libraries with blazing-fast speed powered by Rolldown. Use when bui...
skill.author: antfu

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill providing reference material for tsdown bundler. All static findings are false positives: detected 'shell backticks' are markdown code formatting, 'hardcoded URLs' are documentation links, and 'environment access' patterns are documentation examples. No executable code, network requests, or file system operations exist in this skill.

critical_findings.title: Heuristic Alert: Suspicious Behavior Patterns
critical_findings.description: Static analyzer flagged 'dangerous combination: code execution + network + credential access' and 'suspicious combination: filesystem + credentials + network'. These are false positives - patterns detected in documentation examples only.
critical_findings.confidence_reasoning: Detected patterns are documentation examples showing child_process for build tooling and environment variable examples. No actual malicious code exists in this documentation skill.

high_findings.title: External Command Execution Patterns
high_findings.description: Multiple locations flagged for 'Ruby/shell backtick execution' and 'Node.js child_process module' usage.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Backticks are markdown code formatting syntax, not Ruby shell execution. child_process references are documentation examples for build scripts, not actual code execution.

high_findings.title: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm References
high_findings.description: Found references to weak cryptographic algorithms in documentation.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: These are mentions of algorithms in documentation contexts (e.g., 'md5' in example config paths), not actual cryptographic code. This is a documentation skill with no cryptographic operations.

high_findings.title: Sensitive Data Access Patterns
high_findings.description: Found 'environment file access' and 'environment variant files' patterns.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: These are documentation examples showing how to load .env files in user configurations, not credential access by the skill itself. The skill is documentation-only.

low_findings.title: Hardcoded URLs in Documentation
low_findings.description: Found hardcoded URLs throughout documentation files.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: URLs are documentation links to project resources (tsdown.dev, GitHub, Rolldown). No network requests are made by this skill - it only provides reference documentation.

low_findings.title: Environment Variable Access Patterns
low_findings.description: Found process.env and dot notation access patterns.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: These are documentation examples showing how users can access environment variables in their own configurations. The skill itself does not read any environment variables.

low_findings.title: File System Access Patterns
low_findings.description: Found synchronous file operations and hidden file access patterns.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: These are documentation topics about how tsdown handles file system operations, not actual file system access by the skill. This is a documentation-only skill.

content.value_statement: Building TypeScript libraries requires complex bundler configuration. This skill provides comprehensive documentation for tsdown, a blazing-fast bundler powered by Rolldown, covering configuration, plugins, and migration from tsup.
actual_capabilities: Bundle for multiple output formats (ESM, CJS, IIFE, UMD)
Configure tree shaking and minification for optimal bundle size
Build React, Vue, Solid, and Svelte component libraries
Use lifecycle hooks for custom build logic
Integrate Rolldown, Rollup, and Unplugin plugins
limitations: This skill provides documentation only; it does not execute build commands
CSS handling is experimental and still in development
Does not replace need for understanding bundler concepts and configuration

use_cases.title: Set up a new TypeScript library project
use_cases.description: Create configuration for a new npm library with proper entry points, type declarations, and multi-format output.

use_cases.title: Migrate from tsup to tsdown
use_cases.description: Follow migration guide to convert existing tsup configurations with minimal changes while gaining performance benefits.

use_cases.title: Configure CI-aware builds
use_cases.description: Set up conditional configuration that runs validation and publishing checks only in CI environments.

prompt_templates.title: Basic library setup
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I configure tsdown to bundle my TypeScript library? I need entry points, ESM and CJS formats, and automatic type declarations.
prompt_templates.scenario: Setting up a new library project

prompt_templates.title: Framework component library
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I build a React/Vue component library with tsdown? What configuration do I need for JSX, Fast Refresh, and peer dependency handling?

prompt_templates.title: Migration from tsup
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a tsup.config.ts file. How do I migrate it to tsdown? What options work the same and what has changed?

prompt_templates.title: Advanced plugin integration
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I use Rolldown plugins with tsdown? I need to integrate a WASM plugin and custom transformations.

output_examples.input: How do I generate type declarations with tsdown?
What format options does tsdown support?
output_examples.output:
tsdown supports multiple output formats:
- **esm**: ES Modules (modern browsers, Node.js)
- **cjs**: CommonJS (Node.js legacy)
- **iife**: Immediately Invoked Function Expression (browser globals)
- **umd**: Universal Module Definition (browser + Node.js)

Usage:
```ts
format: ['esm', 'cjs', 'iife']  // Multiple formats
```

Use the external option to prevent bundling specific packages:

```ts
export default defineConfig({
  entry: ['./src/index.ts'],
  external: [
    'react',           // String match
    /^@myorg\//,       // Regex patterns
    /^lodash/,         // Package scope
  ],
})
```

Use noExternal to force bundling:
```ts
noExternal: ['dep-to-bundle']
```

best_practices: Always generate type declarations (dts: true) for TypeScript libraries to provide proper type information to consumers.
Externalize runtime dependencies like React, Vue, or Lodash to avoid bundling duplicate copies in consumer projects.
Validate packages in CI before publishing using publint and attw options to catch common package configuration issues.
anti_patterns: Bundling dependencies that should be external (increases bundle size and causes version conflicts in consumer projects).
Disabling tree shaking when building libraries (prevents consumers from importing only what they need).
Publishing without type declarations (breaks TypeScript type checking for library consumers).

faq.question: What is tsdown?
faq.answer: tsdown is a blazing-fast bundler for TypeScript and JavaScript libraries. It is powered by Rolldown and the Oxc parser, offering significantly faster build times than alternatives like tsup or Rollup.

faq.question: How does tsdown compare to tsup?
faq.answer: tsdown is a modern replacement for tsup with faster performance. Most tsup configurations work with minimal changes. tsdown offers a migration tool (npx tsdown-migrate) to convert existing configs automatically.

faq.question: Does tsdown generate TypeScript declaration files?
faq.answer: Yes. Set dts: true in your configuration to generate .d.ts files alongside your bundled output. Advanced options include sourcemaps, custom compiler options, and Vue single-file component support.

faq.question: What output formats does tsdown support?
faq.answer: tsdown supports ESM (ES Modules), CJS (CommonJS), IIFE (for browser globals), and UMD (universal format). You can output multiple formats simultaneously by specifying an array like format: ['esm', 'cjs'].

faq.question: Can I use tsdown with React or Vue component libraries?
faq.answer: Yes. tsdown supports React (with JSX transform and Fast Refresh) and Vue (SFC support and JSX). Configuration examples are available in the recipe guides for each framework.

faq.question: How do I validate my package before publishing?
faq.answer: Use the publint and attw options in your config. Set them to 'ci-only' to run validation only in CI environments: { publint: 'ci-only', attw: 'ci-only' }. This catches common package issues before publication.
